sep.seeter.server

Class Server

  • java.lang.Object
    • sep.seeter.server.Server
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.lang.AutoCloseable

    public class Server
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.lang.AutoCloseable
    Server is a minimal but adequately functional and robust Seeter server for you to develop and test your client against.

    The argument required to run the server corresponds to Server(int): the port number that the server should listen on.

    You can compile and run Server using NetBeans (e.g., Run -> Set Project Configuration -> Customize... -> New...).

    Assuming you have compiled using NetBeans (or another method), you can also run Server from the command line:

    • Run:
      C:\...\seeter> java -cp build\classes sep.seeter.server.Server 8888

    Note: On some platforms (e.g., Windows), you may be prompted with a security warning due to the Server opening a network socket. You must allow this for the Server to function.

    An instance of Server understands and communicates the messages in sep.seeter.net.message.

    • Bye - tells the Server to end this communication session with the sender client.
    • TopicsReq - request the set of topics recorded by the Server.
      • TopicsReply - the Server's reply: the set of topics (possibly empty).
    • SeetsReq - request the (sub)list of seets recorded by the Server for the specified topic, from the specified index (inclusive, starting from index 0). Note: The topic may not be explicitly recorded by the Server.
      • SeetsReply - the Server's reply, the list of seets (possibly empty).
    • Publish - append a (non-empty) list of seets to each (possibly new) topic in the (non-empty) set of topics.

    Your client should use ClientChannel top send and receive messages of the above types with Server: see the ClientChannel.send(Message) and ClientChannel.receive() methods.

      • Server

        public Server(int port)
       throws java.io.IOException
        Create a new Seeter servSock, bound to the specified port. This is equivalent to Server(false, port).
        Parameters:
        port - The port number that the servSock will listen on
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If the servSock socket could not be opened

      • Server

        public Server(boolean debug,
              int port)
       throws java.io.IOException
        Create a new Seeter servSock, bound to the specified port, with debug output enabled or disabled.
        Parameters:
        debug - Enable or disable local debug output printing (true means enabled)
        port - The port number that the servSock will listen on
        Throws:
        java.io.IOException - If the servSock socket could not be opened
